lesson_objectives: • In this lesson, you'll learn why mobile is popular and what you can do with Android.

• Read the syllabus now. Make sure you understand the flow of each weekly unit:

    Syllabus

• Installation: Follow the instructions at Google's website to install the SDK:

    http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html

    You can just choose the 'Download the SDK' option if you are installing on Windows. For other platforms, follow the links on thatsite.
  • HelloWorld: Go to http://developer.android.com/training/index.htmlUnder Get started > Building Your First App, do Creating an Android Project and Running Your Application. You can run it on theemulator or a real device. Show me. (You should have done this in our face to face meeting. If not, then send me a video of therunning app.)

• In this lesson, you'll see the development of a simple app that one could create 'out of the box' with no experience in Android. Don't worry if you don't absorb every detail. I just want to warm you up so that we can start off strong in the next unit.
• There is no lab for this unit. To finish the unit, please complete the 'Introduction' self-evaluation survey in Moodle.

• In this lesson, you'll learn about the files that are created in a vanilla Hello World project. You will also be introduced to 3 apps that we will write in this unit: Hello Button, Tic Tac Toe (both together in the videos), and LightsOut (the lab)
• In this lesson, you'll learn about making UIs from a specification, including layouts and string and color resources.
• This lesson teaches you how to use button's onClickListeners, and you'll learn how to grab views from the layout, and strings and colors from your resource files.

lesson_title: MVC and Tic Tac Toe Model
lesson_objectives: • This lesson is about the Model-View-Controller design pattern and how Android supports it. We look briefly at a model for a TicTacToe game.
• More practice creating UIs to specification. Introducing TableLayouts.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to respond when listing to multiple buttons.

• The lab specification is here.
  • When done, be sure to submit your zipped Eclipse projects (MyFirstApp and LightsOut), plus video demos, to the Moodle dropbox.
  • Then go complete the Moodle 'Buttons and MVC' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.

• In this lesson, you'll learn about apps that have multiple screens (Activities). You'll also learn about mechanisms for communicating information between activities: Intent extras and SharedPreferences.
  • You'll also see the app that you will write in this unit: Lights Out with Menu (LOM)
  • This unit is longer than the previous one (lectures totalling 132 minutes, plus two labs), so please budget your time wisely.
  • You will also have an exam on basic interactive apps at the end of this unit.

• The lab specification is here.
  • For this mini-lab, please submit to Moodle: the answers to the questions plus your video demos. (You will create several mini projects; you don't need to submit the code for these now, but I may ask for them at the end of the course.)

• In this lesson, you'll review how to make a simple app from scratch.
  • We'll start it together, and it will pause at about 5:00 for you to try it. The rest of the video is completely optional: it's there in case you get stuck. You might want to watch from 9:30 - 10:30 if you want a short description of how Android uses padding in the layout.

• In this lesson, you'll learn how to create and launch new activities using Intents.
  • You'll also learn about the Dialog Theme that you can use for activities.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to use a RadioGroup of RadioButtons so that we can change the size of our LightsOut game board.

• In this lesson, you'll learn how to pass data from one intent to another using extras.
  • You'll also learn the callback to use when you want the second activity to return data back.
• In this lesson, you'll review MVC and launching activities using intents by setting up the LightsOutActivity.

lesson_title: Lights Out Activity Part 2: Creating Views in Code
lesson_objectives: • In this lesson, you'll learn how to create views like table rows and buttons in code, so that your Lights Out game can support a variable number of buttons.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to deal with the effects of a rotated screen by creating a new xml file in the layout-land folder.

• In this lesson, you'll learn how to persist (store after the app stops running) simple data. This is needed to store the number of buttons chosen, which would be lost during a screen rotation. We'll review the activity lifecycle and use a very simple storage solution, SharedPreferences.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to make your app use values like Strings depend on the locale (language).

• The lab specification is here.
  • When done, be sure to submit your zipped Eclipse project (BasketballJersey), plus video demo, to the Moodle dropbox.
  • Then go complete the Moodle 'Intents and Activities' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
• In this lesson, you'll get an overview of the three types of menus we'll study: menu items on the ActionBar, submenus, and the Contextual Action Bar

lesson_title: Menu Items in the Action Bar
lesson_objectives:
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to add menu items to the ActionBar declaratively (using xml) and how to respond to them programmatically (using a callback).
  • There is also a 3 minute tangent on sending emails from your app using the ACTION_SENDTO intent.
• In this lesson, you'll learn about submenus.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to make a custom action bar replace the given one to give more information about an item.
• In this lesson, you'll learn where to find Android's custom icons and how to create your own. This is important if you post your app on Google Play.

• The lab specification is here.
  • When done, be sure to submit your zipped Eclipse project (Snakes), plus video demo, to the Moodle dropbox.
  • We'll wait until after the dialogs unit to complete the 'Menus and Dialogs' self-evaluation survey.
• In this lesson, you'll get an overview of the various types of dialogs you can use in your apps.
• In this lesson, you'll learn about standard very flexible AlertDialogs.

• In this lesson, you'll learn how to show a list of items instead of a message in one of three ways: items only, radio buttons, or checklists.
  • You'll also learn about array resources.
• In this lesson, you will learn how to make custom dialogs, and learn how to correct subtle bugs caused by incorrect use of findViewById

• The lab specification is here.
  • When done, be sure to submit your zipped Eclipse projects (DateTimePickers and Blackjack Dialogs), plus video demo, to the Moodle dropbox.
  • Then go complete the Moodle 'Menus and Dialogs' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
• This unit consists of a short overview of fragments and a detailed lab. This lesson is an extended introduction to the concepts you'll learn about in the lab.

• The lab specification is here.
  • When done, be sure to submit your zipped Eclipse project (Fragments), plus video demo, to the Moodle dropbox.
  • We'll wait until after the dialogs unit to complete the 'Fragments and Adapters' self-evaluation survey.
• In this lesson, you'll get an overview of what adapters are and what types of adapters and adapter views are available.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to create a ListView and populate it using an array and the simplest of ArrayAdapters.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to override the methods in this abstract class.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to replace each item in a ListView with other single views like buttons and images.

• In this lesson, you'll learn how to extend LinearLayout in code so you can serve up compound views as items in the ListView.
  • We display real data (month names) in the rows.
  • Finally, we give the layout a nice, notepage-looking format declaratively.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to extend the ArrayAdapter class

• There is no lab in this unit.
  • However, we still look at directions for further study on adapters.
  • Also, please complete the Moodle 'Fragments and Adapters' self evaluation survey before calling it a day.
